evidence.text: The case is currently pending before the Court without any appeal filed.
Education Sciences Reform Act (“ESRA”) requires that the federal government maintain robust educational data collection capabilities
violates the APA because it was carried out in excess of statutory authority, was arbitrary and capricious, and was not in accordance with the law under ESRA
National Academy of Education, ... and National Council on Measurement in Education

extracted.value: Plaintiffs: Individual, described as National Academy of Education and National Council on Measurement in Education

evidence.text: Both matters are before the same Court. Defendants also proffer cases discouraging 'duplicative' and 'parallel' litigation, but these are inapposite because they generally involve the same parties across multiple cases.
ORDER DENYING Plaintiffs' 14 Motion for Preliminary Injunction.

evidence.text: Defendants request a stay until after the conclusion of a similar case that is pending in this Court.
The Court declines to stay this case for the following reasons.

evidence.source_document: Plaintiffs’ Memorandum of Law in Support of Their Motion for a Preliminary Injunction
evidence.text: Defendants have cancelled over $900 million in contracts necessary for the maintenance and operation of data collected by IES. Defendants have also halved the Department’s overall workforce and imposed even starker layoffs at IES and NCES, shrinking IES’s workforce from over 175 to 20 employees, and NCES’s workforce from approximately 100 employees down to three.

evidence.source_document: Plaintiffs’ Memorandum of Law in Support of Their Motion for a Preliminary Injunction
evidence.text: Defendants have cancelled contracts necessary for the maintenance and functioning of several datasets relied on by Plaintiffs and their members, including: (1) contracts for the National Postsecondary Student Aid Study (NPSAS); (2) contracts necessary to the Common Core of Data (CCD); (3) surveys necessary for the completion of the congressionally required NAEP and EDFacts; (4) contracts supporting the analysis and quality assurance of NAEP data; (5) contracts supporting the operation and availability of the WWC; (6) contracts for the Trends in International Math and Science Study (TIMSS); and (7) contracts through which NCES completes congressionally-mandated longitudinal data collections.

extracted.value: Defendants cancelled over $900 million in contracts for Institute of Education Sciences (IES) data collection, reduced IES staff from 175 to 20 employees and NCES from 100 to 3, restricted access to data including pausing restricted-use data licenses, and terminated contracts for key datasets (NAEP, EDFacts, NPSAS) to hinder Plaintiffs' research on educational disparities.
